message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The continuous murmur along the upper left sternal border indicates a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Indomethacin is used to close a PDA, and is therefore the most appropriate next step in management. Prostaglandin E1 infusion is used to keep PDA open in certain congenital heart diseases. Percutaneous surgery and digoxin and furosemide are not appropriate for PDA closure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The continuous murmur along the upper left sternal border suggests the diagnosis of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Prostaglandin E1 infusion is used to treat ductal-dependent lesions in which the PDA is the only source of pulmonary blood flow, but in this case, it is not necessary because the patient is not in shock. Percutaneous surgery may be an option in older children but not in infants. Digoxin and furosemide are not used to treat PDA. Indomethacin infusion is used to close the PDA in premature infants, and it is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The continuous murmur along the upper left sternal border suggests patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Prostaglandin E1 infusion would be used to maintain patency of a ductus arteriosus if it closes prematurely, but in this case, the PDA is causing problems and needs to be closed. Percutaneous surgery can be an option for larger children, but it may not be appropriate for a 1-month-old infant. Digoxin and furosemide are used for heart failure, which is not yet present in this patient. Indomethacin infusion is used to close a PDA in infants.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the continuous murmur and the infant's history of being born prematurely suggest patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug that can help close a PDA. Prostaglandin E1 infusion is used to keep a PDA open in certain neonatal heart disorders. Percutaneous surgery is not typically used in infants and digoxin and furosemide are not appropriate for the treatment of PDA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and murmurs suggest a diagnosis of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), which is common in premature infants. Indomethacin is a drug that can close the PDA. Prostaglandin E1 infusion can be used in other conditions like hypoplastic left heart syndrome to keep the ductus open. Percutaneous surgery and digoxin and furosemide are not appropriate treatments for PDA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The continuous murmur along the upper left sternal border suggests patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Indomethacin is used to close PDA in premature infants.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest that the infant has a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug that can help close the PDA. Prostaglandin E1 infusion is used to keep the PDA open if there is a critical congenital heart disease. Percutaneous surgery and digoxin and furosemide are not appropriate treatments for PDA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The continuous murmur and symptoms suggest a diagnosis of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Indomethacin is used to close a PDA, and is the most appropriate next step in management after confirming the diagnosis via echocardiography.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The continuous murmur along the left sternal border suggests a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), which is confirmed via echocardiography. Indomethacin is used to treat PDA in preterm infants, and the patient was born at 36 weeks' gestation. Prostaglandin E1 infusion would be used if there was a need to maintain ductal patency, but the patient has PDA which needs to be closed. Percutaneous surgery and digoxin and furosemide are not appropriate management for PDA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the continuous murmur suggest the most likely diagnosis is patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Indomethacin is used to close PDA in premature infants. Prostaglandin E1 infusion is used to keep PDA open in critically ill neonates. Percutaneous surgery and digoxin and furosemide are not appropriate for this condition.
